title: AB 1534
content: The State of California enacts the following. The Legislature in California requires county assessors to adhere to complex state laws to ensure consistent and accurate property assessment practices statewide. Staff must be certified to make decisions regarding property exemptions and changes in ownership to protect taxpayers' interests. The Legislature in California requires county assessors to follow state laws efficiently and economically, utilizing existing resources. Appraisal work contracts must be competitively bid and can be fixed fee or hourly rate with a maximum amount. A contractor in California must maintain the confidentiality of assessee information and records as required by specific sections of the law. The assessor is responsible for requesting information from the assessee, and the contractor can only request additional information with the assessor's written authorization. A contractor in California must maintain the confidentiality of assessee information and records. They are prohibited from sharing appraisal data with assessors or contractors from other counties not involved in the contract. After the contract ends, the contractor must purge and return any assessee records to the assessor within 90 days. The contractor in California must maintain confidentiality of assessee records and return them to the assessor after the contract ends. Contracts must include provisions prescribed by the State Board of Equalization. A contractor is defined as a person not employed by the state, county, or city who performs appraisal work for an assessor. Article 8.5 of the Revenue and Taxation Code requires assessors to hold a valid assessment analyst certificate to make decisions on changes in ownership and property tax exemptions, excluding homeowners' exemption claims. The board administers examinations for assessment analyst certificate applicants, in collaboration with the Department of Human Resources. Exams are prepared by the board with input from a committee of assessors. A passing grade is required for certification, demonstrating competency in making ownership change or exemption decisions as defined by board regulations. The board administers exams for assessment analyst certificate applicants to demonstrate competency in ownership change or exemption decisions. Applicants denied certification have the right to a review under the Administrative Procedure Act. The board administers exams for assessment analyst certificate applicants. To retain a valid certificate, certified assessment analysts must complete 24 hours of training annually approved by the board. This section does not apply to assessors or persons with valid appraiser's certificates. No charges are imposed for exams, certification, or board-approved training. To maintain a valid certificate, certified assessment analysts must complete 24 hours of board-approved training annually. Excess training hours can be carried over for up to three years. Failure to comply may result in certificate revocation following the Administrative Procedure Act. The board requires certified assessment analysts to undergo annual training on new legal developments. An advanced assessment analyst certificate can be obtained after three years of holding a certificate by completing an advanced course of study or passing an advanced level examination. The board, with the help of assessors, will prescribe the course and prepare the examination. To maintain an advanced assessment analyst certificate, holders must complete 12 hours of training annually. Any excess training hours can be carried over for up to two years. Failure to complete training may lead to revocation of the advanced assessment analyst certificate, with proceedings conducted according to the Administrative Procedure Act. Training for certificate retention includes updates on case law, statutory law, and administrative rules. Applicants must disclose financial interests in legal entities at certification and annually thereafter. Each applicant must disclose their financial interest in any legal entity at certification and annually thereafter. Duplicate filings with the Fair Political Practices Commission may fulfill this requirement. The board may issue a temporary certificate to a newly elected or appointed assessor or a newly employed person in the county assessor's office for up to one year to allow them to take an examination. The certificate cannot be renewed. The board may issue an interim certificate to a current assessor or employee of the county assessor's office for up to four years to allow them to take an examination. The certificate cannot be renewed. This article allows assessors to efficiently manage staff resources for noncertificated staff to assist with exemption applications and change in ownership documents. It applies only in counties that have passed a resolution requiring certification.
